THUNDERCLAP
Part III

<italic>Table of Contents</italic><italic></italic><italic></italic><italic></italic>
















 
 

<italic></italic>
<italic>Acronyms & Style</italic>
To communicate intention faster and more directly, <italic>Thunderclap</italic> makes several simplifications. Congressional acts combine category and year. Holding companies and corporations identified with “HC”. “MM” prefixes identify short-term liquid debt money markets. Names of people are not <italic>italicized</italic>, but <italic>firm</italic> names are and do not use definite articles. Some other institutional proper nouns are also <italic>italicized</italic>. Acronyms are generally not <italic>italicized</italic>. Descendancy is usually direct. Cousinhood is often of the first order, unless a surname, then usually implies several marriages between the surnamed families. Middle names are either maternal or maiden surnames. Some surnames have been changed for differentiation from others (e.g., Smith to Smyth).


<italic>Panics of 1933 & 1937</italic>
In 1916, Congress founded the <italic>Federal Farm Loan Board System </italic>(“FFLB”) to supply European allies with agricultural products. While FFLB issued tax-exempt debt, joint-stock land banks (“JSLBs”) without joint-liability made mortgages. With debt, farms and cooperatives—exempt from AA1914 since 1922—mechanized and improve lands as electrification from Insull expanded efficiency. 
As Southern cotton particularly suffered after the <italic>Panic of 1920</italic>, President Coolidge promoted Eugene Meyer from the defunct WFC to chair an emergency cotton commission and control dumping. By September 1930, President Hoover appointed Meyer as the first Jewish Governor of FRS to spur the leaderless system—since FRS <italic>New York</italic> Governor Strong died in 1928—into action.
While Harlem developer Henry Guggenheim Morgenthau Sr served as Wilson’s Ambassador to Turkey, his secular son, Henry Jr, worked with Hoover’s <italic>Food Administration</italic> project. In 1916, he wed Elinor Fatman, a cousin of <italic>Lehman</italic> and <italic>Lazard</italic> New York Frank Altschul’s cousin-in-law. Elinor’s mother worked with Eleanor Roosevelt, and the two became close friends. Henry Jr also became friends with FDR after polio struck the latter in 1921. 
After retaining Francis Perkins from Governor Smith’s administration, FDR also gained the support of friend and supporter of Soviet and German socialism, Averell Harriman. FDR also befriended Democrat bankers. Since Tennessee-born Christian Waddill Catchings withdrew as President of <italic>Goldman </italic>in 1930, working class Sidney Weinberg took over management and supported FDR. 
Similarly, Catholic banker Joseph Kennedy supported FDR since working with him during WWI and for campaigning to end Prohibition. Other Democrat bankers included Arthur Seligmann, helped the New Mexican Territory become a state in 1912 and, after WWII, led <italic>First </italic>NB<italic> of Santa</italic> Fe from 1924. Along with helping reorganize Santa Fé county debt resulting from railroad aid and courthouse bonds, he led the Irrigation Commission. From 1931, Seligmann became New Mexico’s first native-born governor not of Spanish ancestry until his death in 1933.
Despite doubling in numbers since 1900, Jews accounted for 80 thousand out of America’s 30 million farmers. Efforts to transition Jews from urban centers to rural colonies have faced limited success, likely due to historical legal barriers in European landownership for Jews. While early attempts, such as Major Noah’s ‘Ararat’ in 1818 and ‘Sholom’ in Ulster County, New York, between 1837 and 1850, were unrealized or short-lived, <italic>Hirsch</italic>’s endeavors after Russian pogroms were limited to places like the Woodbine in Cape May County, New Jersey.
Meanwhile, Southern PUs could not afford to charge rural subsistence farmers as families. While the number of Northeast farms fell most by 1930, Southern tenancy set a record. Serf-like sharecroppers made up 77% of Black and 45% of Whites. Establishing 134 banks since 1888, Black-owned bank assets peaked in 1926. Many failed after 1929 and only 12 of the 134 still existed in 1936, including Maggie Walker’s <italic>Consolidated Bank & Trust</italic> (1903) and Herman Perry’s <italic>Citizens Trust</italic> (1921). 
JSLB assets peaked in 1927, when three JSLBs fell into receivership. As these entities were bankrupt under BA1926, JSLBs stockholders’ double liability politicized Midwestern banking. Coolidge appointed Eugene Meyer to reorg FFLB, but Congress did not give FFLB receivership powers like UST had for NBs in 1930 or exempt JSLBs from AA1914 per FRS. Instead, <italic>life insurance companies</italic> (“LICs”) tripled Ohio farm acquisitions.
Since the North’s first Black LIC, <italic>Liberty</italic> LIC of Chicago merged with <italic>Supreme </italic>of Columbus and <italic>Northeastern</italic> of Newark in 1929, John Rockefeller Jr stabilized his control stake in the world’s largest LIC, <italic>Equitable</italic>. Having sold off <italic>Citi</italic> in 1909, he bought New York’s largest bank, <italic>Chase</italic>, from <italic>Kuhn</italic> in 1930 to fuse with the family’s <italic>Equitable Trust</italic>. While <italic>Chase</italic>’s Albert Wiggin became CEO of the new entity, <italic>Equitable</italic>’s Winthrop Aldrich became President. 
While Winthrop was a son of Nelson Aldrich—Rhode Island’s Senator and father of FRS with Paul Warburg—his sister married John Rockefeller Jr in 1901. Graduating <italic>Harvard</italic> and <italic>Harvard </italic>Law, Winthrop served in the Naval Reserve during WWI. After becoming associated with <italic>Rockefeller</italic> during the proxy fight for control of <italic>OIL</italic><italic> of Indiana</italic> in the 1920s. By August 1930, <italic>Chase</italic> bought investment bank <italic>Harris Forbes</italic>, and President of <italic>Harris Forbes</italic> Boston John Macomber became Chair of the new <italic>Chase Harris Forbes</italic>. As John Rockefeller Jr’s son Nelson wed Mary Roberts Clark—whose father was Enoch Clark’s grandson and mother was a daughter of <italic>PENN</italic>’s George Roberts—that year, his cousin James Stillman Rockefeller joined <italic>Citi</italic>.
While Jewish banks promoted relatives, they also hired Christians. Soon after promoting the sons of three partners—including Mortimer Schiff’s John, Otto Kahn’s Gilbert, and Felix Warburg’s Frederick, who had trained at <italic>Lehman</italic>—in 1931, <italic>Kuhn</italic> added Lehman-in-law Benjamin Buttenwieser and the <italic>Blair</italic>-alum Christian Elisha Walk by 1932. Since the mostly Christian <italic>Lazard</italic> London promoted Robert Kindersley’s son Hugh to Managing Director, David Langhorne Astor joined as a clerk after he graduated <italic>Oxford</italic>, but he transitioned to journalism two years later, a field more in line with his interests. Even in France, <italic>Rothschild</italic> Paris’ Édouard hired his son’s tutor, René Fillon, as a Department Head that year.
When <italic>Speyer</italic> Frankfurt liquidated in 1934, <italic>Speyer</italic> New York hired George Lindsay as a Partner. The Christian Lindsay joined <italic>Salamon</italic> in 1904, where he remained until her merger with <italic>Blair</italic>. He served as a Partner there until 1932, when he advised RFC and was fiscal agent for FHLB’s <italic>Home Owners</italic><italic>’</italic><italic> Loan Corp</italic> in DC.
Since fusing <italic>International Acceptance </italic>IHC into <italic>Manhattan </italic>NB, Paul Warburg died in 1932. As <italic>Kuhn</italic> absorbed the BIHC, elected Christian Hugh Knowlton partner in late 1932. Since Hugh Knowlton married Christine Stanley in 1917, he became VP of <italic>International Acceptance </italic>in 1926 and later the VP of <italic>International Manhattan</italic>. 
By 1933, most of <italic>Kuhn</italic>’s active partners were not Jews. Jewish partners included Felix Warburg, who was semi-retired, his more active son Frederick, John Schiff, Benjamin Buttenwieser, and Lewis Strauss, managing the syndicate department. While some were secular, converted Otto Kahn, with limited involvement due to health, and his son Gilbert were also partners. Christian-born partners included William Wiseman, active in international affairs, George Bovenizer, who led the bond business, Hugh Knowlton, and Elisha Walk.
Meanwhile, Christine Staney Knowlton’s brother Harold grew from President of <italic>Guaranty Trust </italic>of New York to a <italic>Morgan </italic>partner in 1927 as Morrow left to become Ambassador of Mexico. After promoting Henry Davison Jr and Thomas Lamont to partners in 1929, <italic>Morgan </italic>hired Seymour Gilbert of <italic>Cravath</italic> in 1931 and Charles Dickey of <italic>Brown Harriman </italic>in 1932. While <italic>Kuhn</italic> had non-Jewish partners since 1928, <italic>Morgan</italic>, <italic>Kidder</italic>, and other Protestant banks did not have any Jewish partners until decades after WWII.
Although Ferdinand Eberstadt, a second cousin of <italic>Kuhn</italic>’s Otto Kahn, Paris Rothschilds, and Dreyfus families, was one of <italic>Dillon</italic>’s<italic> </italic>first fellow converted high caste Jews, he resigned in 1931 to go independent and invest in chemicals companies. That year, Douglas Dillon, the son of <italic>Dillon</italic>’s founder, Clarence, bought a NYSE seat and joined the firm after graduating <italic>Harvard</italic>. He also hired his classmate, the descendant of a fellow converted high caste Jew, August Belmont IV, as VP, as <italic>Belmont</italic> dissolved. 
<italic>Dillon</italic> also hired fellow <italic>Harvard</italic> graduate Paul Nitze. While his father was a professor at <italic>Uni of Chicago</italic>, the family relied on his grandfathers’ financial support. One grandfather was a geologist who conducted a survey in Russia and became an Honorary Consul for Russia in Baltimore, the other was a merchant who worked with the North German <italic>Lloyd</italic> and became an Honorary Consul for Germany in Baltimore in 1926. By 1932, Nitze married the granddaughter of an <italic>OIL</italic> co-founder.
While coal inflation raised employment, land values, and municipal taxes, all fell with discoveries of low-labor oil and gas. Congress refused to permit cartels or enact federal regulation. And as ICC prevented price competition, cheap oil and gas reduced demand for coal and trucking costs, lowering railroad profits and financial solvency. Like administered railroad prices, electricity remained stable as deflation and <italic>Attleboro</italic> nullified <italic>Munn</italic>. As state antitrust-inspired oil laws prohibited gas burning, revisions allowed it to stabilize prices from 1931. Likewise, they limited trucking and pushed <italic>Tri Utilities</italic> PUHC into receivership. 
Although Britain and AA1918 American cartels limited trade in the 1920s, Indonesia and the Soviet Union grew exports. However, the <italic>Smoot-Hawley</italic> tariff of 1930 exacerbated farm deflation relative to administered PU and railroad prices. So, as farmer and coaler incomes fell, real debts grew. After Congress purchased and warehoused crops, she sold from 1931, and agricultural collateral loan margins grew. As Chicago banks collapsed, farm bankruptcies grew across FRS <italic>Chicago</italic>’s<italic> </italic>District, particularly in Iowa. Without credit, courts allowed LICs to foreclosures farms. Other states banned corporate farms to decrease prices. As the copper and steel AA1918 supra-national cartels disbanded, commodity prices deflated after the British suspension as the Dutch and Americans remained on gold. While Parliament subsidized <italic>Lazard</italic> London’s Greek PU in 1931, SGE and GGE’s Belgian PUHC continued in Brazil and Spanish America until WWII.
Even as federal UST bonds increased since 1900, municipalities and states accounted for most public debt. With depressed capital markets after the <italic>Panic of 1929</italic>, cities like New York and Detroit—America’s automobile center—reduced municipal spending and unemployment benefits. Within the beleaguered FRS <italic>Chicago</italic> district, Michigan’s largest BHCs—Detroit’s <italic>Guardian</italic> and <italic>Detroit Bankers Co</italic>—satisfied withdrawals by selling or pledging liquid assets for RFC loans. By 1932, they had had only illiquid real estate and municipal debt. While Detroit’s largest taxpayer and employer, motor company <italic>For</italic><italic>d</italic>, supported <italic>Guardian</italic> BHC via deposits rather than capital investment. 
After the <italic>Panic of 1932</italic>, Congress established the FRS-like <italic>Federal Home Loan Bank System </italic>(“FHLB”) to discount non-farm real estate mortgages. However, it remained little used. Since FA1927 promoted secondary mortgages over amortization, banks could not reorg mortgages without realizing losses and lost bankruptcy priority. While RFC aid quelled the <italic>Panic of 1932</italic>, Congress rebuked Chicago’s aid request. As yields collapsed, FRS stopped buying UST bonds. When RFC bailed out RFC President Charles Dawes’ Chicago bank, Congress made permanent FA1932’s discounting to nonbanks and disclosure requirements in July 1932. 
But transparency stigmatized borrowing and banks shied away. Still, RFC lent to municipalities—that had not defaulted—on self-liquidating revenue bond collateral to aid unemployed laborers and poor farmers. In addition to aiding collieries and oil drillers with depletion allowances, TA1932 extended <italic>Smoot-Hawley</italic> with tariff-like excise taxes on these raw materials. By 1933, Congress disclosed all prior RFC recipients. As bank shares sank, BHCs wrote down their assets.
Earlier, Michigan voters destabilized municipal budgets by limiting rising real property taxes in the 1932 election. When RFC increased loans to the <italic>Ford</italic>-affiliated <italic>Guardian</italic> BHC, Michigan’s senator—and <italic>Ford</italic> co-founder—held these illegal in RFC oversight. As he called on <italic>Ford</italic> to subordinate deposits, <italic>Ford</italic> threatened to withdraw them. As President Hoover mediated this negotiation, RFC pulled away, and—without panic—the governor enacted a state-wide bank holiday. 
Unable to tap banks, Detroit defaulted on her debt. Meanwhile, farmers rioted as foreclosures increased. From January 1933, LICs halted foreclosures—and investment—until state debt reforms. In response, Iowa led farm states in mortgage moratoria. As the moratoria destabilized banks, more states enacted bank holidays. For the first time in decades, Americans ran from banks nationally. As Cleveland’s <italic>Union Trust</italic> and <italic>Guardian</italic> <italic>Trust</italic> were forced to reorg, <italic>Guardian Trust</italic> was liquidated, and <italic>Union Commerce Bank</italic> emerged. 
While continuing to propagate antisemitic diatribes during the crisis, demagogues, including two Catholics—Louisiana’s populist Democratic Governor Huey Long and radio personality turned priest Charles Coughlin—soon incorporated President-elect FDR into their conspiracy theories amid the turmoil. Also in January, Rockefeller-in-law<italic> </italic>Winthrop Aldrich of <italic>Chase</italic> advocated separating commercial banking from securities underwriting, and placing banks under the authority of FRS, which his father helped create. As CEO Albert Wiggin resigned in January 1933, and Aldrich became Chair. 
FRS reduced rates but refused to suspend FRS District Bank reserve requirements, like during the <italic>Panic of 1920</italic>. UST bond yields grew with gold suspension fears, forcing FRS to increase rates in late February. During the moratorium in March, Aldrich again advocated separating commercial banking from securities underwriting and urged that all commercial banks be brought under FRS oversight. 
Since the <italic>Pecora Hearings</italic> against bankers started in 1932, <italic>Citi</italic> faced intense scrutiny by 1933. During the hearings, <italic>Citi</italic><italic>’</italic>s Chair Charles Mitchell confessed to selling stock to his wife in 1929 to avoid taxes. Months before Mitchell was acquitted, he drew public ire and resigned from <italic>Citi</italic> during the scandal. Instead, Boston Brahmin James Perkins became Chair of <italic>Citi</italic> and overhauled her capital structure. Graduating <italic>Harvard</italic> and working at various banks, Perkins became a colonel during WWI and was then elected President of <italic>Farmers</italic><italic>’</italic><italic> Loan & Trust</italic>. As the latter affiliated with <italic>Citi</italic> in 1929, Perkins became President of <italic>Citi Farmers Trust </italic>and a <italic>Citi</italic> director. And as <italic>Citi</italic> promoted Gordon Rentschler to President in 1929, his brother Frederick expanded <italic>United Aircraft.</italic> Their niece married Mitchell’s son by 1936. 
While Perkins had the approval of <italic>Citi</italic>’s influential director Percy Rockefeller, the latter resigned in 1933 due to poor health, allowing Floyd Carlisle, head of <italic>Niagara Hudson </italic>PUHC and Chair of <italic>Consolidated Gas </italic>PUHC, to expand his influence. Ill health also forced Sidney Mitch to resign from SGE, whose son subsequently assumed leadership of <italic>Bonbright</italic>. As Landon Thorne and his brother-in-law Alfred Loomis—a cousin of John Morgan’s former lawyer Henry Stimson—left <italic>Bonbright</italic>, they were elected directors and executive committee members of the <italic>Morgan</italic>-affiliated <italic>Bankers Trust</italic>, having purchased John Rockefeller’s stock block.
Instead of devaluation, President Hoover chose debt reorgs. With  on March 3rd, Hoover’s Congress federalized reorgs for individuals, farmers, and railroads. BA1933 removed BA1926’s insolvency requirement for filing and allowed majority compositions to cram down reorgs to dissenting secured creditors. Of these, only railroad filings exploded. Since Hoover refused to declare a national bank holiday, more states declared bank holidays. The governor of Illinois refused to declare a holiday unless New York acted first, and Governor Lehman of New York initially refused to declare a holiday until asked by a responsible authority in the state. Pennsylvania’s governor was difficult to reach and had to be roused by a fire truck. 
Upon his March 4th inauguration, FDR extended bank holidays nationally, with moratoria on NYSE, the <italic>Chicago Board of Trade</italic>, and insurance payouts. Although municipalities, businesses, and relief agencies already circulated scrip, bank clearinghouses now issued certificates. Among the bankers FDR’s administration contracted with for a plan to reopen the banks was Republican James Loeb Warburg, who then supported the <italic>New Deal</italic> and later served as America’s monetary delegate in London.
Banks reopened after FRS vouched for solvency and Congress enacted the  (“EBA”). EBA stopped the bank runs by allowing non-bankruptcy bank conservation and majority compositions to cram down dissenting shareholders. Instead of monetizing UST bonds, EBA empowered FRS to create gold-less bank money. While hiring <italic>Morgan</italic>-affiliated Woodin as UST Secretary, FDR appointed Henry Morgenthau Jr to lead FFLB. After EBA, FDR consolidated federal farm financing into <italic>Farm Credit Administration</italic> (“FCA”) under Morgenthau. For Deputy Governor of FCA, FDR appointed his wife’s uncle, William Morgs, a broker who descended from Elder John Strong.
In late March 1933, stockholders filed suits for receivership of <italic>Detroit Bankers Co</italic> and <italic>Guardian</italic> BHCs, while RFC and UST appointed conservators and arranged for <italic>General </italic><italic>Motor</italic>, <italic>Chrysler</italic><italic> Motor</italic>, and <italic>Ford</italic> <italic>Motor</italic> to underwrite stock for depositors and stockholders, leading to the formation of NB<italic> of Detroit</italic>. Soon after, <italic>Guardian</italic> and several banks were merged into the newly formed <italic>Manufacturers</italic> NB <italic>of Detroit</italic> with investment from <italic>Ford</italic> and RFC and advice from <italic>First Security</italic>’s Eccles clan.
Meanwhile, <italic>title and mortgage insurance companies</italic> (“TICs”) survived the real estate and NYSE downturn because of geographic diversification and account substitution. TICs paid investors out of corporate accounts since they lacked legal instruments to reorganize creditor payouts. Then in March, New York’s regulators required them to make investment payouts using only income. For the first time, these firms suspended payments and debilitated investors. By April, FDR used EBA authority to take America off the gold standard. He ordered individuals and corporations to deposit gold coins and certificates above a $100 exemption. 
While FRS Governor Eugene Meyer steered Hoover’s emergency measures, he resigned from FDR’s Administration by May. Since Baptist deacon Eugene Black Sr became President of <italic>Atlanta Trust Co</italic> and Governor of FRS <italic>Atlanta</italic>, FDR appointed Black as FRS Governor after Meyer. While Eugene’s Heller brother-in-law kinterlinked with <italic>Anglo-California Bank</italic>’s Fleishhackers since 1919, <italic>OIL</italic> California invested in <italic>Anglo-California Bank</italic> in 1933 and the Fleishhackers broker their kinterlink with the Hellers soon after.
For Secretary of Labor, FDR promoted Boston Brahmin-cousin Francis Perkins from head of <italic>State Industrial Commissioner</italic> to the first female Cabinet member from 1933. As she extended her policies from New York nationally, she soon had her hands full. Supporting Joseph Kennedy, the <italic>Anheuser</italic><italic> </italic><italic>Busch</italic> family, and Canadian Bronfmans, FDR kept his campaign promise to end Prohibition, and thus stimulated the ‘official’ economy and raising taxes away from the illegal bootleggers.
As the Court reinterpreted <italic>Munn</italic>-set PU rates from ‘forecast reproduction’ to ‘non-confiscatory’ on May 8th, Congress sought to stabilize farms with the <italic>Emergency Farm Act</italic> (“EFA”) on the 12th. EFA liquidated JSLBs, paid farmers to not grow—favoring<italic> </italic>America’s South relative to Puerto Rico and other colonies, and allowed UST to set the <italic>dollar</italic><italic>’</italic><italic>s</italic> gold to UST debt ratio. 
By the 18th, FDR signed bill for the  (“TVA”) to federally dam the Tennessee River for hydroelectricity and electrify the South under the direction of David Lilienthal. While waiting for the Court to opine, Lilienthal created the <italic>Electric Home & Farm Authority</italic> to subsidize and stimulate consumer purchases of electric appliances—primarily refrigerators, ranges, and hot water heaters—and forge a political economy of mass consumption. 
After Chicago’s <italic>Illinois</italic> LIC failed in 1933, her Chair Raymond Stevens and his father, who had the founded the LIC, were tried for embezzlement. As his father died, Stevens committed suicide, but his son-in-law, George Champion, returned to <italic>Chase</italic> as second VP. Following the failure of <italic>Illinois</italic> LIC, auditors revalued other LIC real estate. As the multi-state Black-led <italic>Supreme</italic>’s assets dropped in half, bankruptcy seemed likely with minimal funds and profits. 
<italic>Supreme</italic>’s Counsel Earl Dickerson’s plan of uncertain legality had policyholders sign liens for half of their policy reserves. Despite later prohibition, Illinois’ Court validated these liens as assets, aided by Dickerson, also Illinois’ assistant attorney general.  By then, after dozens of Black-owned banks shuttered since 1930, only eight survived the <italic>Dust Bowl</italic> trauma. With two in Philadelphia, these other banks were in Nashville, Atlanta, Newport News, Durham, Charleston, and Richmond, where Maggie Walker’s bank thrived for decades after her death in 1934.
By October, Congress chartered the<italic> Commodity Credit Corp </italic>(“CCC”) to guarantee crop profits. And, the same day as EFA, the<italic> </italic> (“EMA”) reduced municipal tax burdens with RFC grant transfers for public work housing and other services. Despite EMA, New York City negotiated with banks through 1933 to roll over increasingly expensive debt. 
Since WWI, Julius Cohen Based on British public benefit corporations that pioneered as counsel for America’s first <italic>authority</italic>—<italic>Port Authority of New York & New Jersey</italic>—innovated multipurpose, inter-jurisdictional construction from 1916. However, <italic>Port Authority </italic>remained unique until RFC and EMA, as <italic>authorities</italic> financed self-liquidating projects by issuing tax-exempt bonds that RFC discounted. As off-balance-sheet entities, <italic>authorities</italic> were not subject to constitutional public debt limits. By 1931, Governor FDR appointed Cohen Vice Chair and Counsel of <italic>Saint-Lawrence Water Power Commission</italic>. Representing <italic>Hoover Dam</italic> contractors since 1930, California’s <italic>Heller Ehrman </italic>law firm worked with RFC, Congress, and California to finance <italic>Golden Gate Bridge</italic>.<italic> </italic>(Still, developers asked <italic>TransAmerica</italic> to buy a large chunk).
While the Depression squeezed many stocks and IHCs, <italic>Atlas</italic> and <italic>DuPont</italic>’s IHC remained solid. In April 1933, <italic>Atlas </italic>gained control of <italic>Goldman</italic>’s IHC after a minority investment the previous year, which became the nucleus for her IHC system. Since Rockefeller-in-law Marcellus Hartley Dodge’s <italic>Remington Rand</italic> sold her cash register division to <italic>National Cash Register Co</italic> in 1931, he sold her rifle business to chemical giant <italic>DuPont</italic> in May. Within days, Congress introduced federal securities law.
As Congress attributed the growth of Kreuger’s IHC to financial misreporting, they adopted the inaugural , based on the 1929 British mandate for security issuers to certify financial reports. <italic>Sullivan </italic>partner Arthur Dean, a member of FDR’s anti-Wall Street ‘Brain Trust’, helped to draft SA1933 in a single weekend. Initially opposed, Dean guided the drafters to ensuring a truthful presentation of securities. SA1933 established new regulations for issuing stocks and bonds to the public, requiring full and fair disclosure of securities’ character to prevent fraud. 
Dean’s experience in preparing registration statements allowed him to argue against undue emphasis on historical aspects to prevent burying important facts in irrelevant detail. Per Dean, SA1933 required counsel opinions, ensuring lawyers continued to play an important role in securities issuance and compliance. Initial drafts of SA1933 excluded municipal bonds, small firms, and over-the-counter traded securities. However, the latter was eventually deleted while the others were retained.
So, the trend to publicly traded securities markets that grew in the 1920s collapsed. While <italic>Lehman</italic> helped PUs and others sell SA1933-exempt private debt to LICs, failure rates were steady. As contracts continued to have gold clauses, Congress nullified such obligations on June 5. Within days Eaton’s <italic>Continental </italic>IHC defaulted on collateral loans. Only Insull’s bankruptcy was larger. NYSE soon required Cyrus Eaton’s Cleveland bank <italic>Otis</italic> to sell herself to <italic>Pierce</italic>.
After Eaton fought Rockefeller’s <italic>Bethlehem Steel</italic> from merging with <italic>Youngstown</italic>, Rockefeller’s <italic>Chase</italic> NB auctioned much of Eaton’s collateral with <italic>Dillon</italic>’s aid.  Leaving <italic>Chase</italic> NB in 1934, Charles McCain became President of Eaton’s <italic>United Light & Power Co </italic>PUHC, as <italic>OIL</italic>-in-law and <italic>Dillon</italic> banker Paul Nitze became a director of<italic> United Light</italic>’s principal subsidiary. While the Mellons also had large interests in<italic> United Light</italic>, <italic>Rockefeller</italic> yielded <italic>Bethlehem Steel </italic>to <italic>Morgan </italic>and Mellon interests after Percy Rockefeller died in 1934. So, Percy’s uncle, John Rockefeller Jr, set up trusts with oil stocks and real estate, which made up most of his family’s fortune into the 21st century. Meanwhile, <italic>Chase</italic> director Eugene Rensselaer Thayer served as receiver for Insull’s <italic>Mississippi Valley </italic>PUHC.
On the 13th, Congress empowered FHS to charter and regulate federal <italic>savings and loans</italic> (“S&Ls”). Ohio, Michigan, and Chicago B&L SBs with similar structures converted to refinance and discount mortgages with FHS. Although securities affiliates raised bank solvency and liquidity,  forced separation of the two activities on June 16, as <italic>Chase</italic>’s Winthrop Aldrich had lobbied. While this was a goal of FA1913, Midwest securities firms—Eaton and <italic>Stuart</italic>—and Rockefeller’s <italic>Chase </italic>aligned with <italic>Morgan</italic>. Per FA1933, <italic>Chase</italic> and her <italic>American Express </italic>affiliate sold their stake in <italic>Corn Exchange Bank Trust </italic>(“CEBT”)—which <italic>Chase</italic> had acquired before Rockefeller took over—to <italic>Lehman</italic>, which had founded CEBT’s predecessor in 1873—to disperse broadly. 
<italic>Chase</italic>, <italic>Morgan</italic>, <italic>Brown</italic> <italic>Harriman</italic>, <italic>Citi</italic>, and <italic>First </italic>NB<italic> of Boston</italic> were among the few to remain NBs, their securities financiers left to found independent firms. When <italic>Chase</italic> dissolved <italic>Harris Forbes</italic>, Eugene Black Jr chose to join <italic>Chase</italic> NB in New York, where he oversaw sales across 8 Southern states.
